newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq, China sign $1.2 billion oil contract.
newsitem.headline: Iraq, China sign $1.2 billion oil contract.

text.p: Iraq and China Wednesday signed a $1.2 billion contract to develop the vast Ahdab oilfield in southern Iraq, Chinese and Iraqi officials said.

"Just now we signed al-Ahdab oilfield," Zhou Yong-Kang, chairman of the Chinese National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC), told reporters. "Indeed it is a pleasant occasion to sign the important al-Ahdab oil contract between two friendly countries Iraq's Oil Minister Amir Muhammad Rasheed said.
The field, which contains an estimated 1 billion barrels of oil, is near Kut, 110 miles south of Baghdad.

Rasheed said the cost of the project, which would be implemented over 22 years, was estimated at $660 million while operation costs were put around $600 million. He said the deal would bring Iraq a total of $10 billion in revenues.
Rasheed said the field would produce 90,000 barrels a day.
He said the Iraqi government and the National Assembly (parliament) had ratified the contract.

"Therefore it is ready for implementation as from tomorrow," he added. U.N. trade sanctions imposed for Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait place a blanket ban on export investment in the country, but the U.N. has allowed Iraq to pump $2 billion worth of oil over six months to pay for humanitarian purchases.

Zhou said China would start work on aspects that did not violate the United Nations sanctions. "Of course, some of the works would be restricted...We would begin with preparatory and drilling works," he said.
Asked how China would finance the project, Zhou said: "It would be through two channels...the CNPC itself and international financial organisations and banks."
China is also interested in the development of the prized Halfaya field in the south.
"We have serious discussions on the Halfaya field. We will continue discussions on this oilfield until its fruitful conclusion, hopefully in the near future," Rasheed said.
Halfaya was discovered 20 years ago and is believed to hold commercial reserves of about 5 billion barrels. Iraq believes the field could produce some 250,000 barrels a day at full capacity.

Iraq and Russia in March signed a $3.5 billion contract to develop up to 8 billion barrels of reserves in southern Iraq's Qurna oilfield, 300 miles south of Baghdad. The deal will be implemented over 23 years.
